3 Calculus of variations

3.1 Introduction 3.2 Optimality criteria 3.3 Weak extrema 3.4 Piecewise extremal functions 3.5 Constrained problems

3.5 Problems with equality and inequality constraints

We now turn our attention to problems of the calculus of variations in the presence of constraints. Similar to finite-dimensional optimization problems, it is more convenient to use Lagrange multipliers in order to derive the necessary conditions of optimality associated with such problems; these considerations are discussed in the following for equality constraints. The method of Lagrange multipliers is then used in to obtain necessary conditions of optimality for problems subject to (equality) terminal constraints and isoperimetric constraints, respectively. The Lagrange multiplier methodology is then extended to inequality constrained problems.

We start by considering a general class of equality constraints where the function space ùíü is defined by level-set curves of one ore more functionals G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n g .

Definition 3.11: Equality constrained calculus of variations problem

Consider the problem to minimize:

min ⁡ x ( t ) F [ x ] = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 f ( t , x ( t ) , x Àô ( t ) ) d t s . t . x ‚àà ùíü ‚äÇ ùí≥

where ùíü : = { x ‚àà ùí≥ such that G i [ x ] = K i i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n g } .

The functionals G i are defined in ùí≥ as well.

Remark 3.19

Note that also the basic problem of Calculus of Variations we have addressed so far falls into this broader category. Consider the functionals G 1 [ x ] = x ( t 1 ) and G 2 [ x ] = x ( t 2 ) and recall that for the basic problem we had ùíü : = { x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x such that x ( t 1 ) = x 1 , x ( t 2 ) = x 2 } . We can define the same ùíü as ùíü : = { x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x such that G 1 [ x ] = x 1 and G 2 [ x ] = x 2 } .

Remark 3.20: Common types of constraint functionals

This kind of problems allow to treat more general problems such as endpoint constrained problems and isoperimetric problems. In the endpoint constrained case the constraint functionals G i take the form G i [ x ] = œà i ( t 2 , x ( t 2 ) ) for i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n x . The constraint reduces to G i [ x ] = 0 i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n x , in this way the final state is forced to satisfy œà ( t 2 , x ( t 2 ) ) = 0 . Isoperimetric problems are a class of problems where the constraint functionals are defined as G [ x ] = ‚à´ ⁡ t 1 t 2 g ( t , x , x Àô ) d t and the constraint is expressed as the level-set G [ x ] = L where L ‚àà ‚Ñù . These kind of constraints are found in minimum volume [area] problems with fixed area [perimeter] as for example the catenary or Dido‚Äôs problem that we will solve in the following sections.

The next theorem that we give without proof is instrumental to prove a fundamental lemma on the existence of minimizers of such equality constrained problems.

Theorem 3.11: Inverse Function Theorem

Let x 0 ‚àà ‚Ñù n x and Œ∑ > 0 . If a function Œ¶ : ‚Ñ¨ Œ∑ ( x 0 ) ‚Üí ‚Ñù n x has continuous first partial derivatives in each component with nonvanishing Jacobian determinant at x 0 , then Œ¶ provides a continuously invertible mapping between ‚Ñ¨ Œ∑ ( x 0 ) and a region containing a full neighborhood of Œ¶ ( x 0 ) .

The following Lemma gives conditions under which a point x ¬Ø in a normed linear space ( ùí≥ ; ‚Äñ ‚ãÖ ‚Äñ ) cannot be a (local) extremal of a functional F , when constrained to the level set of another functional G .

Lemma 3.5

Let F and G be functionals defined in a neighborhood of x ¬Ø in a normed linear space ( ùí≥ ; ‚Äñ ‚ãÖ ‚Äñ ) , and let G [ x ] = K be the equality constraint defining ùíü . Suppose that there exist fixed directions Œæ 1 , Œæ 2 such that the G√¢teaux derivatives of F and G satisfy the Jacobian condition:

| Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] | ‚â† 0

and are continuous in a neighborhood of x ¬Ø (in each direction Œæ 1 , Œæ 2 ). Then, x ¬Ø cannot be a local extremal for F when constrained to ùíü : = { x ‚àà ùí≥ such that G [ x ] = K } .

Proof. Consider the auxiliary functions j ( Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 ) : = F [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 Œæ 2 ] and g ( Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 ) : = G [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 Œæ 2 ] , we have j ( 0 , 0 ) = F [ x ¬Ø ] and g ( 0 , 0 ) = G [ x ¬Ø ] = K and by definition of G√¢teaux derivative Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] = ‚àÇ j ‚àÇ Œ∑ 1 | 0 , 0 = j Œ∑ 1 ( 0 , 0 ) , Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] = ‚àÇ j ‚àÇ Œ∑ 2 | 0 , 0 = j Œ∑ 2 ( 0 , 0 ) , Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] = ‚àÇ g ‚àÇ Œ∑ 1 | 0 , 0 = g Œ∑ 1 ( 0 , 0 ) and Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] = ‚àÇ g ‚àÇ Œ∑ 2 | 0 , 0 = g Œ∑ 2 ( 0 , 0 ) . Let us also define the function Œ¶ : ‚Ñù 2 ‚Üí ‚Ñù 2 as:

Œ¶ = [ j ( Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 ) g ( Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 ) ] ,

the jacobian determinant of Œ¶ at ( 0 , 0 ) is:

Det ( J Œ¶ ( 0 , 0 ) ) = | j Œ∑ 1 ( 0 , 0 ) j Œ∑ 2 ( 0 , 0 ) g Œ∑ 1 ( 0 , 0 ) g Œ∑ 2 ( 0 , 0 ) | = | Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] Œ¥ F x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 1 ] Œ¥ G x ¬Ø [ Œæ 2 ] | ,

by hypothesis we have Det ( J ( 0 , 0 ) ) ‚â† 0 and thence Theorem 3.11 is applicable. Therefore the pre-image points of the neighborhood of Œ¶ ( 0 , 0 ) = [ j ( 0 , 0 ) , g ( 0 , 0 ) ] ‚ä§ ⁡ = [ F [ x ¬Ø ] , K ] ‚ä§ ⁡ maps a full neighbourhood of the origin ( 0 , 0 ) in the Œ∑ 1 - Œ∑ 2 plane as shown in Figure 3.12. That means that we can find ( Œ∑ 1 √ó , Œ∑ 2 √ó ) and ( Œ∑ 1 o , Œ∑ 2 o ) such that:

j ( Œ∑ 1 o , Œ∑ 2 o ) < j ( 0 , 0 ) < j ( Œ∑ 1 √ó , Œ∑ 2 √ó ) g ( Œ∑ 1 o , Œ∑ 2 o ) = g ( 0 , 0 ) = g ( Œ∑ 1 √ó , Œ∑ 2 √ó ) = K ,

by definition of the functions g and j we have:

F [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 o Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 o Œæ 2 ] < F [ x ¬Ø ] < F [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 x Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 x Œæ 2 ] G [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 o Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 o Œæ 2 ] < G [ x ¬Ø ] < G [ x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 x Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 x Œæ 2 ] = K ,

that means that x ~ = x ¬Ø + Œ∑ 1 o Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 o Œæ 2 is admissible (i.e. satisfy the constraint G [ x ~ ] = K ) and reduces the cost, that is F [ x ~ ] < F [ x ¬Ø ] hence x ¬Ø cannot be a local extremal trajectory. ‚ñ°

With this preparation, it is easy to derive necessary conditions for a local extremal in the presence of equality or inequality constraints, and in particular the existence of the Lagrange multipliers.

Theorem 3.12: Existence of the Lagrange Multipliers

Let F and G be functionals defined in a neighborhood of x ‚ãÜ in a normed linear space ( ùí≥ , ‚Äñ ‚ãÖ ‚Äñ ) , and having continuous G√¢teaux derivatives in this neighborhood. Let also K = G ( x ‚ãÜ ) and suppose that x ‚ãÜ is a (local) extremal for F constrained to Œì ( K ) : = { x ‚àà ùí≥ : G ( x ) = K } . Suppose further that Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] ‚â† 0 for some direction Œæ ¬Ø ‚àà ùí≥ . Then, there exists a scalar Œª ‚àà ‚Ñù such that:

Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] + Œª Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ Œæ ‚àà ùí≥ a a Note that the variations need not to be admissible for the space  Œì ( K ) . .

Proof. Since x ‚ãÜ is a (local) extremal for F constrained to Œì ( K ) by Lemma 3.5 we must have that the determinant:

| Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] | = 0

for any Œæ ‚àà ùí≥ Hence, by defining:

Œª : = ‚àí Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ]

it follows that Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] + Œª Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] = 0 for each Œæ ‚àà ùí≥ . ‚ñ°

Remark 3.21

As in the finite-dimensional case, the parameter Œª in Theorem 3.12 is called a Lagrange multiplier. Using the terminology of directional derivatives appropriate to ‚Ñù n x , the Lagrange condition Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] = ‚àí Œª Œ¥ G x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] says simply that the directional derivatives of F are proportional to those of G at x ‚ãÜ . Thus, in general, Lagrange‚Äôs condition means that the level sets of both F and G at x ‚ãÜ share the same tangent hyperplane at x ‚ãÜ i.e., they meet tangentially. Note also that the Lagrange‚Äôs condition can also be written in the form

Œ¥ ( F + Œª G ) x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ Œæ ‚àà ùí≥

This is due to the linearity of the G√¢teaux derivative that is, given two scalars a 1 , a 2 ‚àà ‚Ñù and two functionals A , B from ùí≥ to ‚Ñù we have that Œ¥ ( a 1 A + a 2 B ) x [ Œæ ] = a 1 Œ¥ A x [ Œæ ] + a 2 Œ¥ A x [ Œæ ] as shown in Remark 3.7 which suggests, as we will see in the following, consideration of the Lagrangian functional L : = F + Œª G .

It is possible, ableit technical, to extend the method of Lagrange multipliers to problems involving any finite number of constraint functionals:

Theorem 3.13: (Existence of the Lagrange Multipliers (Multiple Constraints)

Let F and G i , i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ n g be functionals defined in a neighborhood of x ‚ãÜ in a normed linear space ( ùí≥ , ‚Äñ ‚ãÖ ‚Äñ ) and having continuous G√¢teaux derivatives in this neighborhood. Let also K i = G i [ x ‚ãÜ ] , i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n g and suppose that x ‚ãÜ is a (local) extremal for F constrained to Œì ( K ) : = { x ‚àà ùí≥ : G i [ x ] = K i , i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n g } . Suppose further that:

| Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n g ] ‚ãÆ ⁡ ‚ã± ‚ãÆ ⁡ Œ¥ G n g , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G n g , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n g ] | ‚â† 0

for n g (independent) directions Œæ ¬Ø 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , Œæ ¬Ø n g ‚àà ùí≥ . Then, there exists a constant vector Œª ‚àà ‚Ñù n g such that:

Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] + ‚àë i = 1 n g Œª i Œ¥ G i , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ] = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ Œæ ‚àà ùí≥

Remark 3.22: Link to Nonlinear Optimization

The previous theorem is the generalization of Theorem 2.13 of Chapter 2 to optimization problems in normed linear spaces. Note, in particular, that the requirement that x ‚ãÜ to be a regular point for the Lagrange multipliers to exist is generalized by a non-singularity condition in terms of the G√¢teaux derivatives of the constraint functionals G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n g . Yet, this condition is in general not sufficient to guarantee uniqueness of the Lagrange multipliers.

Remark 3.23: Hybrid Method of Admissible Directions and Lagrange Multipliers

If x ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíü with ùíü a subset of a normed linear space ( ùí≥ , ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ) , and the ùíü -admissible directions form a linear subspace of ùí≥ (i.e., Œæ 1 , Œæ 2 ‚àà ùíü ‚áí Œ∑ 1 Œæ 1 + Œ∑ 2 Œæ 2 ‚àà ùíü for every scalars Œ∑ 1 , Œ∑ 2 ‚àà ‚Ñù ), then the conclusions of Theorem 3.12 remain valid when further restricting the continuity requirement for F to ùíü and considering ùíü -admissible directions only. Said differently, Theorem 3.12 can be applied to determine (local) extremals to the functional F | ùíü constrained to Œì ( K ) . This extension leads to a more efficient but admittedly hybrid approach to certain problems involving multiple constraints. Those constraints on which determine a domain ùíü having a linear subspace of ùíü -admissible directions, may be taken into account by simply restricting the set of admissible directions when applying the method of Lagrangian multipliers to the remaining constraints.

Necessary conditions of optimality for problems with end-point constraints and isoperimetric constraints shall be obtained with this hybrid approach in the next subsections.

3.5.1 Problems with end-point constraints

So far, we have only considered those problems with either free or fixed end-time t 1 , t 2 and end-points x ( t 1 ) , x ( t 2 ) . In this subsection, we shall consider problems having end-point constraints of the form œï ( t 2 , x ( t 2 ) ) = 0 with t 2 being specified or not. In the case t 2 is free, t 2 shall be considered as an additional variable in the optimization problem. Like in 3.3.1 we shall then define the functions x ( t ) by extension on a ‚Äùsufficiently‚Äù large interval [ t 1 , T ] , and consider the linear space ùíû 1 [ t 1 , T ] n x √ó ‚Ñù , supplied with the weak norm ‚à• ( x , t ) ‚à• 1 , ‚àû : = ‚à• x ‚à• 1 , ‚àû + | t | . In particular, Theorem 3.13 applies readily by specializing the normed linear space ( X , ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ) to ( ùíû 1 [ t 1 , T ] n x √ó ‚Ñù , ‚à• ( ‚ãÖ , ‚ãÖ ) ‚à• 1 , ‚àû ) and considering the G√¢teaux derivative Œ¥ F x , t 2 [ Œæ , œÑ ] at ( x , t 2 ) in the direction ( Œæ , œÑ ) . These considerations yield necessary conditions of optimality for problems with end-point constraints as given in the following:

Theorem 3.14: Transversal Conditions

Consider the problem to minimize the functional

F [ x , t 2 ] : = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 f ( t , x ( t ) , x Àô ( t ) ) d t

on ùíü : = { ( x , t 2 ) ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , T ] n x √ó [ t 1 , T ] : x ( t 1 ) = x 1 , œï ( t 2 , x ( t 2 ) ) = 0 } with f ‚àà ùíû 1 ( [ t 1 , T ] √ó ‚Ñù 2 √ó n x ) and œï ‚àà ùíû 1 ( [ t 1 , T ] √ó ‚Ñù n x ) n x . Suppose that ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) gives a (local) minimum for F on ùíü and Rank [ œï t œï x ] = n x at ( x ‚ãÜ ( t 2 ‚ãÜ ) , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) . Then, x ‚ãÜ is a solution to the Euler equation of Theorem 3.3 satisfying both the end-point constraints x ‚ãÜ ( t 1 ) = x 1 and the transversal condition:

[ ( f ‚àí f x Àô x Àô ) d t + f x Àô d x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ [ d t d x ‚ä§ ⁡ ] ‚àà Ker [ œï t œï x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ

in the particular one-dimensional case (i.e. n x = 1 ) the transversal condition reduces to:

[ œï x ( f ‚àí ·∫ã f ·∫ã ) ‚àí œï t f ·∫ã ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ = 0 .

Proof. G k [ x ] : = œï k ( t 2 , x ( t 2 ) ) = 0 k = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n x ,

where the usual compressed notation is used. Based on the differentiability assumptions on f and œï it is clear that these G√¢teaux derivatives exist and are continuous. | Œ¥ G 1 , ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 , œÑ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G 1 , ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) [ Œæ ¬Ø n x , œÑ ¬Ø n x ] ‚ãÆ ⁡ ‚ã± ‚ãÆ ⁡ Œ¥ G n x , ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 , œÑ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G n x , ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) [ Œæ ¬Ø n x , œÑ ¬Ø n x ] | ‚â† 0

Œû : = { ( Œæ , œÑ ) ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , T ] n x √ó ‚Ñù : Œæ ( t 1 ) = 0 } . Since ( x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ ) gives a (local) minimum for F on ùíü by Theorem 3.13 and Remark 3.23 there exist a vector Œª ‚àà ‚Ñù n x such that:

[ b t b x ‚ä§ ⁡ ] d = 0

[ ‚àí b t ‚àí b x ‚ä§ ⁡ ] d = 0

[ ( f ‚àí f x Àô x Àô ) d t + f x Àô d x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ [ d t d x ‚ä§ ⁡ ] ‚ä§ ⁡ ‚àà Ker [ œï t œï x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ

Remark 3.24: one-dimensional case

For the one-dimensional case we have:

[ ( f ‚àí f ·∫ã ·∫ã ) d t + f ·∫ã d x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ ( d t d x ) ‚àà Ker [ œï t œï x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ

note that [ œï t œï x ] x ‚ãÜ , t 2 ‚ãÜ = v ‚ä§ ⁡ reduces to a row vector in ‚Ñù 2 then the kernel is simply made of the subspace of vectors in d ‚àà ‚Ñù 2 such that:

v ‚ä§ ⁡ d = 0 ‚Üí d t œï t + d x œï x = 0 ,

by picking d x = ‚àí œï t and d t = œï x the transversality condition reduces to:

Remark 3.25

Note that œï ‚àà ùíû 1 ( [ t 1 , T ] √ó ‚Ñù n x ) n x therefore its Jacobian is a matrix n x √ó ( n x + 1 ) of the form :

Example 3.15 (Minimum Path Problem with Variable End-Point and End-Time). Consider the problem to minimize the distance between a fixed point A = ( x A , y A ) and the point B = ( x B , y B ) ‚àà { ( x , y ) ‚àà ‚Ñù 2 : y = a x + b } in the ( x , y ) -plane. We want to find the curve y ( x ) x A ‚â§ x ‚â§ x B such that the functional F [ y , x B ] : = ‚à´ ⁡ x A x B 1 + ·∫è ( x ) 2 d x is minimized, subject to the constraints y ( x A ) = y A and y ( x B ) = a x B + b . Note that neither x B nor y ( x B ) are explicitly given. Instead they are implicitly given by the scalar end-point constraint œï ( x B , y ( x B ) ) = y ( x B ) ‚àí a x B ‚àí b = 0 where œï : ‚Ñù 2 ‚Üí ‚Ñù is obviously a ùíû 1 function. We stress the fact that œï ( x , y ) = 0 (i.e. the zero level-set of the function œï ) is a straight line in ‚Ñù 2 . Therefore, we are looking for the minimum path problem from a fixed point A to a point B on a given straight line. For the sake of simplicity let‚Äôs consider A = ( 0 , 0 ) , from Theorem 3.14 we know that an extremal y ‚ãÜ must satisfy the Euler equation in the interval x ‚àà [ x A x B ‚ãÜ ] . Note that x B ‚ãÜ is yet unknown. As we have already seen the extremal for minimum path problems are straight lines. Since we have assigned a boundary condition in A , we get:

y ‚ãÜ ( x ) = C 1 x

that are a family of straight lines passing through the origin. In order to find C 1 and x B ‚ãÜ we apply the necessary condition of Theorem 3.14 adpated to the one dimensional case, that is:

[ ( f ‚àí f ·∫è ·∫è ) œï y ‚àí f ·∫è œï x ] y ‚ãÜ , x B ‚ãÜ = 0

Substituting f = 1 + C 1 2 , f ·∫è = C 1 1 + C 1 2 , œï y = 1 , œï x = ‚àí a we get:

1 + C 1 2 ‚àí C 1 2 1 + C 1 2 + a C 1 1 + C 1 2 = 0

and upon simplification:

1 + a C 1 1 + C 1 2 = 0 ‚Üí C 1 = ‚àí 1 a

that precisely means that the extremal curve y ‚ãÜ = ‚àí 1 a x is perpendicular to the straight line defined by the constraint. In this simple case, this is a global condition but the transversality condition in general is a local condition at the end-point between the ‚Äùgradient‚Äù of the constraint and the extremal trajectory. Note that we have also implicitly found x B ‚ãÜ as the intersection between the lines y ‚ãÜ = ‚àí 1 a x and y = a x + b that is x B ‚ãÜ = b a a 2 + 1 . A graphical representation of this problem is shown in Figure 3.13

3.5.2 Problems with isoperimetric constraints

An isoperimetric problem of the calculus of variations is a problem wherein one or more constraints involves a functional in the form of an integral over part or all of the integration horizon [ t 1 , t 2 ] . Typically:

min ⁡ x ( t ) ‚àà ùíü F [ x ] = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 f ( t , x ( t ) , x Àô ( t ) ) d t  subject to:  G [ x ] = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 œà ( t , x ( t ) , x Àô ( t ) ) d t = K

where K ‚àà ‚Ñù is a given number. Note that this problem already fits the framework that we have treated so far since the constraint is in the form of a level-set of the functional G [ x ] . We will use the hybrid approach in Remark 3.23 to deal both with simpler constraints imposed by the function space ùíü (e.g. fixed end-points) and with the isoperimetric constraint G [ x ] = K .

Theorem 3.15: First-Order Necessary Conditions for Isoperimetric Problems

Example 3.18 (Solution to hanging rope with fixed length). We give the solution to the problem shown in Example 3.2 . where again C 1 , C 2 , Œª are to be found from the boundary condition and the length L .

3.5.3 Problems with inequality constraints

The method of Lagrange multipliers can also be used to address problems of the calculus of variations having inequality constraints (or mixed equality and inequality constraints), as shown by the following:

Theorem 3.16: Existence and Uniqueness of the Lagrange Multipliers (Inequality Constraints)

Let F and G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n g be functionals defined in a neighborhood of x ‚ãÜ in a normed linear space ( ùí≥ , ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ) , and having continuous and linear G√¢teaux derivatives in this neighborhood. Suppose that x ‚ãÜ is a (local) minimum point for F constrained to Œì ( K ) : = { x ‚àà ùí≥ : ùí¢ i ( x ) ‚â§ K i , i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n g } for some constant vector K . Suppose further that n a ‚â§ n g constraints, say G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n a for simplicity, are active at x ‚ãÜ and satisfy the regularity condition

| Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚Ä¶ ⁡ Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n a ] ‚ãÆ ⁡ ‚ã± ‚ãÆ ⁡ Œ¥ G n a , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G n a , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n a ] | ‚â† 0

for n a (independent) directions Œæ ¬Ø 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , Œæ ¬Ø n a ‚àà ùí≥ (the remaining constraints being inactive). Then, there exists a vector ŒΩ ‚àà ‚Ñù n g such that:

Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] + ‚àë i = 1 n g Œ¥ G i , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø ] ŒΩ i = 0 ‚àÄ ⁡ Œæ ‚àà ùí≥

and

ŒΩ i ‚â• 0 ( G i [ x ‚ãÜ ] ‚àí K i ) ŒΩ i = 0

for i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n g

Proof. Since the inequality constraints G n a + 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n g are inactive, the nonnegativity conditions and complementary slackness are trivially satisfied by taking ŒΩ n a + 1 = ‚ãØ = ŒΩ n g = 0 . On the other hand, since the inequality constraints G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n a are active and satisfy a regularity condition at x ‚ãÜ , the conclusion that there exists a unique vector Œª ‚àà ‚Ñù n a such that the ‚Äùstationarity condition‚Äù holds follows from Theorem 3.12 moreover, the complementarity slackness condition is trivially satisfied for i = 1 ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n a since G i [ x ‚ãÜ ] = K i if i is active. Hence, it suffices to prove that the Lagrange multipliers ŒΩ i ‚ãØ ŒΩ n a cannot assume negative values when x ‚ãÜ is a (local) minimum.

We show the result by contradiction. Without loss of generality, suppose that ŒΩ 1 < 0 , and consider the ( n a + 1 ) √ó n a matrix A defined by

A = [ Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚Ä¶ ⁡ Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n a ] Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚Ä¶ ⁡ Œ¥ G 1 , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n a ] ‚ãÆ ⁡ ‚ã± ‚ãÆ ⁡ Œ¥ G n a , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø 1 ] ‚ãØ Œ¥ G n a , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø n a ] ] .

By hypothesis, Rank ( A ‚ä§ ⁡ ) ‚â• n a ‚àí 1 , hence the null space of A has dimension lower than or equal to 1 . But from the stationarity condition the nonzero vector ( 1 , ŒΩ 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , ŒΩ n a ) ‚ä§ ⁡ ‚àà Ker ( A ‚ä§ ⁡ ) . That is Ker ( A ‚ä§ ⁡ ) has dimension equal to 1 and A ‚ä§ ⁡ y < 0 only if ‚àÉ ⁡ Œ∑ ‚àà ‚Ñù such that y = Œ∑ ( 1 , ŒΩ 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , ŒΩ n a ) ‚ä§ ⁡ . Because ŒΩ 1 < 0 there does not exist a y ‚â† 0 in Ker ( A ‚ä§ ⁡ ) such that y i ‚â• 0 for every i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n a + 1 . Thus, by Gordan‚Äôs Theorem there exists a nonzero vector p ‚â• 0 in ‚Ñù n a such that A p < 0 , or equivalently:

‚àë k = 1 n a p k Œ¥ F x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø k ] < 0 ‚àë k = 1 n a p k Œ¥ G i , x ‚ãÜ [ Œæ ¬Ø k ] < 0 i = 1 , ‚Ä¶ , n a .

The G√¢teaux derivatives of F , G 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , G n a being linear (by assumption), we get:
